senses.sense_definition: Paid or required in advance, before goods are delivered or services are performed.

examples.text: The landlord requires an <w>upfront</w> deposit equal to one month's rent.
There are no <w>upfront</w> fees to join the program, but you pay a monthly subscription later.

senses.sense_definition: Honest, frank, and straightforward about one's opinions, intentions, or situation.

examples.text: He was completely <w>upfront</w> about his lack of experience in this field.
I appreciate you being <w>upfront</w> with me regarding the potential risks.

senses.sense_definition: In advance; before other processes start, especially regarding payment.

examples.text: You need to pay for the concert tickets <w>upfront</w> to secure your seats.
The contractors demanded cash <w>upfront</w> before they would begin the renovation.

senses.sense_definition: In the attacking position of a team sport, particularly football (soccer).

examples.text: The manager decided to play two strikers <w>upfront</w> to put pressure on the defense.
He is very fast and effective when playing <w>upfront</w>.

senses.sense_definition: A meeting of television network executives with the press and advertisers to present the new season's schedule.

examples.text: The network announced several new drama series at this year's <w>upfronts</w>.
Advertisers are waiting for the <w>upfronts</w> to decide where to allocate their budgets.

senses.sense_definition: To bring to the fore; to place at the front for consideration.

examples.text: The author <w>upfronts</w> the main argument in the very first chapter.
This report <w>upfronted</w> the voices of the community members involved in the study.
